column2: The contribution of planting at least three billion additional trees by 2030 at Union level
column5: The implementation of TA6.47 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.11, as the increased tree cover can contribute to carbon sequestration and help achieve the renewable energy targets. This is because trees can provide biomass for energy production, and their growth can also support the development of renewable energy sources.

column2: Member States shall achieve an increasing trend at national level of at least six out of seven indicators in forest ecosystems
column5: The implementation of TA6.48 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as the improvement in forest ecosystem indicators can support the development of renewable energy sources, such as biomass and bioenergy. This is because healthy forests can provide sustainable biomass resources, which can be used to produce renewable energy.

column2: Member States shall achieve an increasing trend at national level of the common forest bird index
column5: The implementation of TA6.49 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13, as the improvement in forest bird populations can indicate a healthy forest ecosystem, which can support the development of renewable energy sources. This is because forest birds can serve as indicators of forest health, and their presence can support the growth of trees and other vegetation that can be used for renewable energy production.

column2: Reach no net land take
column5: The implementation of TA6.50 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15, as reducing land take can help preserve natural habitats and ecosystems, which can support the development of renewable energy sources. This is because preserving natural habitats can help maintain biodiversity, which is essential for supporting ecosystem services that can contribute to renewable energy production.

column2: Member States shall take the measures necessary to ensure that water intended for human consumption is wholesome and clean
column5: The implementation of TA6.51 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as ensuring clean drinking water can support the development of renewable energy sources, such as hydroelectric power. This is because clean water is essential for supporting the operation of hydroelectric power plants, which can generate renewable energy.

column2: The Ambient Air Quality Directives set EU air quality standards for 12 air pollutants
column5: The implementation of TA6.52 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.17, as improving air quality can support the development of renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power. This is because reducing air pollution can help improve the efficiency of renewable energy technologies, which can contribute to achieving the targets set by TA2.17.

column2: The Water Reuse Regulation aims to encourage and facilitate water reuse in the EU by harmonised minimum water quality requirements
column5: The implementation of TA6.62 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as promoting water reuse can help reduce the energy required for water treatment and support the development of renewable energy sources. This is because water reuse can help reduce the amount of energy needed to treat and transport water, which can contribute to achieving the targets set by TA2.21.

column2: The Industrial Emissions Directive aims at preventing or reducing emissions from large industrial installations and intensive farming into the environment
column5: The implementation of TA7.4 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.22, as reducing industrial emissions can support the development of renewable energy sources and improve energy efficiency. This is because reducing emissions can help reduce the amount of energy required to power industrial processes, which can contribute to achieving the targets set by TA2.22.

column2: The revised Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive extends the scope of the 1991 UWWTD to improve and maintain access to sanitation for all
column5: The implementation of TA7.5 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.23, as improving wastewater treatment can help reduce the energy required for wastewater treatment and support the development of renewable energy sources. This is because wastewater treatment can help reduce the amount of energy needed to treat and transport wastewater, which can contribute to achieving the targets set by TA2.23.

column2: Improve soil quality by reducing chemical pesticides’ use by 50% by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA7.6 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as reducing chemical pesticides can help improve soil health and support the development of renewable energy sources, such as bioenergy. This is because healthy soils can support the growth of crops and other vegetation that can be used for renewable energy production.

column2: Improve soil quality by reducing nutrient losses by 50% by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA7.8 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13, as reducing nutrient losses can help improve soil health and support the development of renewable energy sources, such as bioenergy. This is because healthy soils can support the growth of crops and other vegetation that can be used for renewable energy production.

column2: Improve air quality to reduce the number of premature deaths caused by air pollution by 55% by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA7.9 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.17, as improving air quality can support the development of renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power. This is because reducing air pollution can help improve the efficiency of renewable energy technologies, which can contribute to achieving the targets set by TA2.17.

column2: Improve water quality by reducing waste, plastic litter at sea (by 50%) by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA7.10 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as improving water quality can support the development of renewable energy sources, such as hydroelectric power. This is because clean water is essential for supporting the operation of hydroelectric power plants, which can generate renewable energy.

column2: Improve water quality by reducing microplastics released into the environment (by 30%) by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA7.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as reducing microplastics can help improve water quality and support the development of renewable energy sources, such as hydroelectric power. This is because reducing microplastics can help improve the efficiency of hydroelectric power plants, which can contribute to achieving the targets set by TA2.16.

column2: Reduce by 25% the EU ecosystems where air pollution threatens biodiversity by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA7.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.17, as reducing air pollution can help improve the health of ecosystems and support the development of renewable energy sources. This is because healthy ecosystems can support the growth of vegetation and other organisms that can be used for renewable energy production.

column2: Reduce the share of people chronically disturbed by transport noise by 30% by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA7.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as reducing transport noise can help improve the quality of life and support the development of renewable energy sources. This is because reducing noise pollution can help improve the efficiency of renewable energy technologies, which can contribute to achieving the targets set by TA2.21.

column2: Having all soils in healthy condition by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA7.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as healthy soils can support the growth of crops and other vegetation that can be used for renewable energy production. This is because healthy soils are essential for supporting ecosystem services that can contribute to renewable energy production.

column2: By means of an updated and harmonised list of pollutants affecting surface and groundwater
column5: The implementation of TA7.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as reducing pollutants can help improve water quality and support the development of renewable energy sources, such as hydroelectric power. This is because clean water is essential for supporting the operation of hydroelectric power plants, which can generate renewable energy.

column2: Each Member State shall agree to establish a framework for cooperation on joint projects with one or more other Member States for the production of renewable energy
column5: The implementation of TA2.11 may have a negative impact on TA6.47, as the focus on joint projects for renewable energy production may lead to increased land use and competition for resources, potentially threatening the goal of planting three billion additional trees by 2030.

column2: The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.13 may have a negative impact on TA7.6, as the increased demand for renewable fuels and electricity in the transport sector may lead to increased competition for resources, potentially threatening the goal of reducing chemical pesticides by 50% by 2030.

column2: Each Member State shall increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector by at least 0.8 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2021 to 2025
column5: The implementation of TA2.14 may have a negative impact on TA7.8, as the increased demand for renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector may lead to increased competition for resources, potentially threatening the goal of reducing nutrient losses by 50% by 2030.

column2: By 2022, achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target, and its contribution to the 2030 target of the share of energy from renewable sources in gross final consumption of energy
column5: The implementation of TA2.15 may have a negative impact on TA7.9, as the focus on increasing the share of renewable energy may lead to increased air pollution from the production and transportation of renewable energy sources, potentially threatening the goal of improving air quality by 2030.

column2: Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector by an indicative increase of at least 1.6 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the periods 2021 to 2025 and 2026 to 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.16 may have a negative impact on TA7.10, as the increased demand for renewable energy in the industry sector may lead to increased competition for resources, potentially threatening the goal of improving water quality by reducing waste and plastic litter at sea by 2030.

column2: A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.17 may have a negative impact on TA7.11, as the increased focus on electricity interconnection may lead to increased energy consumption and potentially threaten the goal of reducing microplastics released into the environment by 2030.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year, when compared to 2021
column5: The implementation of TA2.21 may have a negative impact on TA7.14, as the focus on reducing energy consumption in public bodies may lead to increased noise pollution from the implementation of energy-efficient measures, potentially threatening the goal of reducing the share of people chronically disturbed by transport noise by 2030.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column5: The implementation of TA2.22 may have a negative impact on TA7.15, as the focus on reducing energy consumption may lead to increased competition for resources, potentially threatening the goal of having all soils in healthy condition by 2050.

column2: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.23 may have a negative impact on TA7.16, as the focus on reducing primary energy consumption may lead to increased competition for resources, potentially threatening the goal of updating and harmonising the list of pollutants affecting surface and groundwater.
